titleStmt.title: Letter, Albert Woodcock in Franklin, Tenn., to Leute, 1863 May 06

publicationStmt.publisher: The University of Tennessee Libraries Digital Initiatives

availability.p: The copyright interests in this collection remain with the creator. For more information, contact the Special Collections Library.

bibl.title: Letter, Captain Albert Woodcock in Franklin, Tenn. to Leute in Place Unknown, 1863, May 6
bibl.note: Capt. Albert Woodcock of the 92nd Illinois who was stationed in Franklin, Tenn. wrote to his wife, Lucy (Lute), on May 6, 1863. He spoke about fatigue and the miserably cold weather. One division had moved out to attack the enemy at Spring Hill. He figured his unit would be sent out before night as a reinforcement. He reminded her to send the Capt. some articles. He hadn't received letters from her everyday so wondered if she was writing daily. He figured everybody at home was busy. He asked about the family. He felt bad that she was alone rearing the children, but told her he knew she could do it well. He told her his company was healthy and working hard and about the daily happenings at camp. He drew a small diagram of his position.

projectDesc.p: Machine-readable transcription created for the University of Tennessee Libraries Special Collections.

revisionDesc.change: Migrating from XML to validated TEI P5.

div.p: I have just finished a letter to brother & sister Noble. You say I must not neglect you for friends. I will endeavor not to. We were out yesterday an fatigue falliing the The air this morning is very diclly & a cold rain is drizzling down. Gen. Gilberts division consisting of 6 Regts moved out to day probably to attack the enemy at Spring Hill. I should not be at all surprised if we should be ordered out before night to reinforce them. Capt. Smith is now at home. I have solid comforts & happiness in my tent when I think how nicely the Capt is enjoying himself. I do hope he will improve in health Lieut Light is in command of the company. The company are getting along finely. I took breakfast at the Caps table yesterday morning; but I should have enjoyed it better had he been present. Dont forget to send by the Capt. the articles I requested. I hope John has got the money I sent I begin to feel uneasy. I juck no letter from you for the past two days, I wonder if you write every day. Well how do things move off at dear old home? I suppose John and Henry are as busy as ever in the Office; you as busy as ever at the sewing machine or caring for the little boys.

How are the children getting along? I could not but notice when at home that Berty had grown somewhat rune dgish . Those little boys need great attention. I sympathise with you dearest One. Dont jail to make them mind when you & sp to them just once. I need not give you advice in this; you doubtless think it is easier to preach than to practise; but I feel a great anxiety for the children though I should not for they are in your wise care. Col Sheets is well. Boys that ar with I me getting along well. We are still working like ants at our fortifications Th following is a rough diagram of our position to

From the above you will get a fai I did of our situation. It is time for the scribbling to go into mail. My love to all. Tell Ca Smith I can take down anything in Co. B & when he back I shall roll him in the nust.Kiss my boys fo me. I embrace you
